STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 5, 2024
Zoe Lyons
Jackson County DHHS
301 E. Louis Glick Hwy,
Jackson, MI, 49201-1535
Re: License #: CP380201203
Dear Ms. Lyons:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
12/14/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services

Chief Administrator: Zoe Lyons
Name of Agency: Jackson County DHHS
Agency Address: 301 E. Louis Glick Hwy
Jackson, MI 49201-1535
Agency Telephone #: (517)780-7600
Original Issuance Date: 03/01/1992
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Supervise
Independent Living, Place children in foster
home

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all the following: (c) A physical examination for
each child as follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated: (i) A comprehensive medical
examination, including a behavioral/mental health and
trauma screening, within 30 calendar days from the date
the child entered into an out-of-home placement,
regardless of the date of the last physical examination.
Three of eight foster care files did not have initial physical exams completed within
the first 30 days of entering care.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all the following: (e) A dental examination must
be completed within 3 months before entry into foster
care or an initial dental examination must be completed
not more than 90 calendar days after entry into a foster
care out-of-home placement.
Two of eight foster care files did not have dental exams completed within the first 90
days of entering care.
2

CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(2) An agency shall maintain a file documentation from
the medical or dental provider of all medical and dental
care received by a foster child.
One of eight foster care and one of three independent living files did not have
documentation from a medical provider to accompany the recorded dates of dental
exams.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child’s record before a change of placement occurs…
One of eight foster care files did not have the required documentation when a child's
placement changed. This information is typically documented on a DHHS-69 form.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child’s
placement at least once every month.
One of eight foster care files was missing one monthly foster home visit with a child.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(6) Service plans must be signed by the social services
worker and the social services supervisor.
One of twenty service plans were not signed by the worker and supervisor.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the child’s parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the parents’ and
the foster parent’s role in assisting the agency in carrying
out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review
the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents...
3

Two of twenty service plans did not have a signature by the parent indicating
participation in development of the plan or receipt of a copy of the plan.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.
One of eight foster care files did not have documentation of any sibling visits.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child…
One of eight foster care files did not have the required information documented prior
to placement.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The agreement
must be reviewed with the youth at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
One of three independent living case files did not have an agreement reviewed and
signed every 90 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/15/22 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 1/12/23
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement
to a youth before placement in independent living.
One of three independent living files did not have documentation the program
statement was reviewed or provided to the youth prior to entering IL.
FOM 722-06b Family Team Meeting
4

FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
• Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
• Semi-annual transition meeting- Within 30
calendar days after the child’s 14th birthday and
every six months thereafter.
Three of twenty service plans did not have a USP completed within 30 days prior to
service plan due date.
Two of eight foster care files did not have semi-annual transition meetings
completed every six months.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/15/22 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 1/12/23
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
Page 2
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Four of eight foster care files did not have medical passports updated as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/15/22 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 1/12/23
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following area:
• Medical Passports-Policy office clarified that medical passports must be
updated quarterly for all youth, even if a foster parent or parent signature is
not required at that time. Medical passports must be updated saved in
MiSACWIS to verify the date it was updated.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
5

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
The CAP, approved 1/12/23, was the result of the 12/15/22 renewal evaluation.
During the 2022 review, twelve licensing rule and DHHS policy violations were
found. The agency reported successful implementation of their CAP over the past
year. Although there has been some staffing changes, which may have affected
full compliance. As of the current review thirteen violations were found. Three of
those violations were repeat violations from the 2022 review. However, it was
noted that each repeat had fewer instances of missing or late information than the
previous year.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed. During this
past year the agency has made effort to inform foster parents of the new licensing
rules and ensure they are in compliance. The agency has also focused on
engagement with families and foster families to improve services. The agency
continues to see a high number of children coming in to care, with placements with
relatives increasing. This relative engagement and follow-up for licensure has
increased responsibilities for licensing and foster care staff. The agency also
continues to have difficulty locating non-relative placements, due to the ongoing
state-wide placement crisis. The agency reports staffing to be steady at this time,
although there has been turnover which creates a lag in some work due to the
time needed to train new staff. Despite these challenges, the agency has
continued working diligently on their CAP throughout this review period. The
agency noted positive outcomes from the CAP as well as some areas where
improvement is needed.
Financial Overview
N/A as local MDHHS office.
Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. One staff was new to the agency and reported
feeling very supported by her supervisor. The staff stated there is great teamwork
and collaboration at the agency and guidance when needed to keep everyone
informed. The staff did not have any suggestions for improvement at the agency.
The second staff has been with the agency for a few years. The staff reported their
supervisor is supportive, on top of everything, and very organized. The staff did
not have any concerns about the agency, but indicated they would benefit from
more service providers in the area. Staff also indicated case aids to help transport
and act as parenting coaches would be nice to have.
Description of Agency Walk Through
6

The agency continues to be located in the same building as the 2022 review. The
building is located in downtown Jackson, MI. The building has sufficient space for
staff and clients. There is adequate locked storage for confidential information
including CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL analyst identified one safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert: The unlicensed relative home did not have any working smoke or
carbon monoxide detectors. Medications were not stored safely.
Resolution: The agency provided the family with a lock box for medication. Agency
staff verified the medication was properly stored in the lock box on 11/2/23. The
agency provided the home with combination smoke/carbon monoxide detectors for
each level of the home. The detectors were installed and tested on 11/2/23.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
_ ___________December 20, 2023_______________
Heather A Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 5, 2024
